elements.content: The mixed donor ligand 2-(phenylazo)imidazole (L 1 ) forms a family of seven different metal complexes of varying coordination environments at the molecular level. The presence of hydrogen bonding sites along with metal coordination sites results in the formation of three-dimensional (3D) self-assembled supramolecular architectures. Variation of the 3D architecture is a consequence of fine-tuning of the coordination behavior of the mixed donor ligand. Compatibility of the hard−soft nature of the metal ion and the mixed donor L 1 controls the long-range 3D order in the solid-state. The solid-state structures of L 1 and their complexes were identified by single crystal X-ray structure analysis. The optical, electrochemical, and thermal properties of azo-dyes and their metal complexes were studied in detail and compared with their molecular structures.

The presence of hydrogen bonding sites along with metal coordination sites results in the formation of three-dimensional (3D) self-assembled supramolecular architectures. Variation of the 3D architecture is a consequence of fine-tuning of the coordination behavior of the mixed donor ligand. Compatibility of the hard-soft nature of the metal ion and the mixed donor L  1  controls the long-range 3D order in the solid-state. The solid-state structures of L  1  and their complexes were identified by single crystal X-ray structure analysis. The optical, electrochemical, and thermal properties of azo-dyes and their metal complexes were studied in detail and compared with their molecular structures.

elements.content: The solid-state multifaceted three-dimensional (3D) architecture of seven metal complexes resulted from the fine-tuning of the coordination behavior of 2-(phenylazo)imidazole (L1 ). Simultaneous presence of hydrogen bond donor and acceptor allows the formation of 3D self-assembled supramolecular hydrogen bonded networks in the crystals. Thermal, absorption spectral and electrochemical studies also have been done.
elements.clean_text: The solid-state multifaceted three-dimensional (3D) architecture of seven metal complexes resulted from the fine-tuning of the coordination behavior of 2-(phenylazo)imidazole (L1 ). Simultaneous presence of hydrogen bond donor and acceptor allows the formation of 3D self-assembled supramolecular hydrogen bonded networks in the crystals. Thermal, absorption spectral and electrochemical studies also have been done.

elements.content: The coordination-controlled self-assembly of molecular complexes in the solid-state is currently emerging as a promising approach toward the design of novel coordination architectures. Construction of metal−organic coordination frameworks via metal coordination-directed self-assembly processes has become an area of intense research in recent years. Imidazole, a nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compound, is a ubiquitous ligand in chemical and biological systems, which also plays an important role in coordination chemistry. This has stimulated the synthesis of imidazole containing ligands and their metal complexes in order to understand the role of the ligand in biological systems. Azo-dyes are widely used in analytical chemistry and dyestuff industry. They have often been used for micro determination of elements when adsorbed on ion exchange resins, either in ion-exchanger colorimetric methods or in the design of chemical optical sensors. Recently, they have received much attention in the field of nonlinear optics, optical storage, and other photoelectric applications. Thermal analysis plays an important role in the study of the structure and stability of dyes. The resistance to heat at elevated temperatures is one of the main properties required of dyes used in high temperature processes such as dyeing, printing, and photocopying and in high technology areas such as lasers and electro-optical devices. Because of the good thermal stability of azo compounds, one of the most important applications of azo compounds is in optical data storage. Derivatives of azo-chromophores with pyrazole or imidazole as the heterocyclic component belong to a class of organic ligands that contain four nitrogen atoms coupled in a conjugated system of π-bonds. We have been focusing on the synthesis, structural, and thermal studies of metal complexes of mixed-donor ligands. To explore the coordination chemistry as well as self-assembly of the azo-imdazole system, we have used a ligand incorporating the phenylazo group in the imidazole heterocycle known as 2(phenylazo)imidazole (L 1 ). The unhindered ligand has two different N-donor metal coordination sites along with an efficient hydrogen bond donor site. It reacts with metal salts in solution and form complexes of varying coordination geometry following basic coordination as well as the HSAB principle (Mn-complex-1, Cu-complex-2, Zn-complex-3, Ru-complex-4, Cd-complex-5, 6 and Hg-complex-7). We have explored the self-assembled supramolecular solid-state structures of seven different metal complexes. We have compared their molecular level structural information with their three-dimensional (3D) solid-state structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The coordination-controlled self-assembly of molecular complexes in the solid-state is currently emerging as a promising approach toward the design of novel coordination architectures. Construction of metal-organic coordination frameworks via metal coordination-directed self-assembly processes has become an area of intense research in recent years. Imidazole, a nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compound, is a ubiquitous ligand in chemical and biological systems, which also plays an important role in coordination chemistry. This has stimulated the synthesis of imidazole containing ligands and their metal complexes in order to understand the role of the ligand in biological systems. Azo-dyes are widely used in analytical chemistry and dyestuff industry. They have often been used for micro determination of elements when adsorbed on ion exchange resins, either in ion-exchanger colorimetric methods or in the design of chemical optical sensors. Recently, they have received much attention in the field of nonlinear optics, optical storage, and other photoelectric applications. Thermal analysis plays an important role in the study of the structure and stability of dyes. The resistance to heat at elevated temperatures is one of the main properties required of dyes used in high temperature processes such as dyeing, printing, and photocopying and in high technology areas such as lasers and electro-optical devices. Because of the good thermal stability of azo compounds, one of the most important applications of azo compounds is in optical data storage. Derivatives of azo-chromophores with pyrazole or imidazole as the heterocyclic component belong to a class of organic ligands that contain four nitrogen atoms coupled in a conjugated system of π-bonds. We have been focusing on the synthesis, structural, and thermal studies of metal complexes of mixed-donor ligands. To explore the coordination chemistry as well as self-assembly of the azo-imdazole system, we have used a ligand incorporating the phenylazo group in the imidazole heterocycle known as 2(phenylazo)imidazole (L  1 ). The unhindered ligand has two different N-donor metal coordination sites along with an efficient hydrogen bond donor site. It reacts with metal salts in solution and form complexes of varying coordination geometry following basic coordination as well as the HSAB principle (Mn-complex-1, Cu-complex-2, Zn-complex-3, Ru-complex-4, Cd-complex-5, 6 and Hg-complex-7). We have explored the self-assembled supramolecular solid-state structures of seven different metal complexes. We have compared their molecular level structural information with their three-dimensional (3D) solid-state structures.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Solvents were distilled freshly following standard procedures. Acetonitrile (MeCN) was dried by distillation from anhydrous CaH2 and stored over 4-Å molecular sieves for electrochemical analysis.

elements.content: The IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer-Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer with KBr disks in the range 4000−400 cm−1. The absorption spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda- 25 UV−vis spectrometer at 298 K. NMR spectra was recorded on a Varian FT-400 MHz instrument. The chemical shifts were recorded in parts per million (ppm) on the scale using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as a reference. Elemental analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 automatic carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen analyzer. The solid-state magnetic susceptibility of the complex at room temperature was recorded using a Sherwood Scientific balance MSB-1. Solution electrical conductivity measurements were made with a Systronics Conductivity meter 306. The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of the compounds were performed by using an SDTA 851 e TGA thermal analyzer (Mettler Toledo) with a heating rate of 2 °C per min in a N2 atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded with Seifert powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD 3003TT) with Cu Kα source (λ = 1.54 Å) on a glass surface of an air-dried sample.

The chemical shifts were recorded in parts per million (ppm) on the scale using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as a reference. Elemental analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 automatic carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen analyzer. The solid-state magnetic susceptibility of the complex at room temperature was recorded using a Sherwood Scientific balance MSB-1. Solution electrical conductivity measurements were made with a Systronics Conductivity meter 306. The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of the compounds were performed by using an SDTA 851 e TGA thermal analyzer (Mettler Toledo) with a heating rate of 2 °C per min in a N2 atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded with Seifert powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD 3003TT) with Cu Kα source (λ = 1.54 Å) on a glass surface of an air-dried sample.

elements.content: Cyclic voltammetric (CV) measurements were carried out using a CH Instruments make CHI660C electrochemistry system. The cell contained a glassy carbon working electrode, a Pt wire auxiliary electrode, and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as reference electrode. A salt bridge (containing supporting electrolyte, tetra-n-butylammonium perchlorate (TBAP) dissolved in dry MeCN) was used to connect the SCE with the electrochemistry solution. All experiments were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere at RT and were uncorrected for junction potentials. Under our experimental conditions, the E 1/2 values (in volts) for the couple Fc+/Fc were 0.45 in MeCN vs SCE.
elements.clean_text: Cyclic voltammetric (CV) measurements were carried out using a CH Instruments make CHI660C electrochemistry system. The cell contained a glassy carbon working electrode, a Pt wire auxiliary electrode, and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as reference electrode. A salt bridge (containing supporting electrolyte, tetra-n-butylammonium perchlorate (TBAP) dissolved in dry MeCN) was used to connect the SCE with the electrochemistry solution. All experiments were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere at RT and were uncorrected for junction potentials. Under our experimental conditions, the E 1/2 values (in volts) for the couple Fc+/Fc were 0.45 in MeCN vs SCE.

elements.content: The intensity data were collected using a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD diffractometer, equipped with a fine focus 1.75 kW sealed tube Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 273(3) K, with increasing ω (width of 0.3° per frame) at a scan speed of 3 s/frame. The SMART software was used for data acquisition. Data integration and reduction were undertaken with SAINT and XPREP software. Multiscan empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the program SADABS. Structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined with full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier maps and refined. Structural illustrations have been drawn with ORTEP-3 for Windows. Selected crystallographic data are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The intensity data were collected using a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD diffractometer, equipped with a fine focus 1.75 kW sealed tube Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 273(3) K, with increasing ω (width of 0.3° per frame) at a scan speed of 3 s/frame. The SMART software was used for data acquisition. Data integration and reduction were undertaken with SAINT and XPREP software. Multiscan empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the program SADABS. Structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined with full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier maps and refined. Structural illustrations have been drawn with ORTEP-3 for Windows. Selected crystallographic data are summarized in Table .

2-(Phenylazo)imidazole ligand (L 1 ) was synthesized following the literature method.

General Synthesis of Metal Complexes

. L 1 (2 mmol) in MeOH (20 mL) was added dropwise to a stirred alcoholic solution (20 mL) of metal chloride salt (1 mmol) at RT. The mixture was stirred for another 1−3 h at RT. For complexes 1 and 7 excess NH4SCN was added to the mixture. The resulting solution was filtered and left undisturbed for crystallization. For the crystallization of complex 5 mixtures of water and ethanol were used.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

2-(Phenylazo)imidazole ligand (L  1 ) was synthesized following the literature method. 

General Synthesis of Metal Complexes

. L  1  (2 mmol) in MeOH (20 mL) was added dropwise to a stirred alcoholic solution (20 mL) of metal chloride salt (1 mmol) at RT. The mixture was stirred for another 1-3 h at RT. For complexes 1 and 7 excess NH4SCN was added to the mixture. The resulting solution was filtered and left undisturbed for crystallization. For the crystallization of complex 5 mixtures of water and ethanol were used.

elements.content: The crystal structure analysis of the ligand L 1 shows that both imidazole and phenyl fragments are planar and the azo group is virtually coplanar with these groups. The dihedral angle between the two least-squares planes is only 2.1°. The NN bond length is 1.254(3) Å, which is smaller than a similar system. The bonding strength between azo-N(4) and phenyl [C(4)−N(4), 1.408(4) Å] is weaker than that of azo-N(3) and imidazole [C(1)−N(3), 1.373(4) Å]. This suggests that the extent of orbital overlap is more between azo and imidazole moieties than azo and phenyl moieties to form a C−N σ-bond. The imidazole N(2)−H2A is intermolecularly hydrogen bonded with a second neighboring imidazole N(1) forming a 1D-chain along the diagonal of the ac plane. The phenyl ring of the molecule is arranged in an alternative direction about the 1D-chain (Figure ). Moderately intense stretching at 1445−1450 cm−1 is due to νN=N, which shows a significant blue shift by 20−25 cm−1 in the complexes relative to the free ligand values.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Studies

The crystal structure analysis of the ligand L  1  shows that both imidazole and phenyl fragments are planar and the azo group is virtually coplanar with these groups. The dihedral angle between the two least-squares planes is only 2.1°. The NN bond length is 1.254(3) Å, which is smaller than a similar system. The bonding strength between azo-N(4) and phenyl [C(4)-N(4), 1.408(4) Å] is weaker than that of azo-N(3) and imidazole [C(1)-N(3), 1.373(4) Å]. This suggests that the extent of orbital overlap is more between azo and imidazole moieties than azo and phenyl moieties to form a C-N σ-bond. The imidazole N(2)-H2A is intermolecularly hydrogen bonded with a second neighboring imidazole N(1) forming a 1D-chain along the diagonal of the ac plane. The phenyl ring of the molecule is arranged in an alternative direction about the 1D-chain (Figure ). Moderately intense stretching at 1445-1450 cm-1 is due to νN=N, which shows a significant blue shift by 20-25 cm-1 in the complexes relative to the free ligand values.

elements.content: Formation of metal complex with the ligand involves the use of imidazole nitrogen, which was involved in the formation of a hydrogen-bonded network of ligand. Thus, in the complex the 1D hydrogen bonded chain has been broken giving rise to a less symmetrical 3D structure. Figure a shows the molecular structure of the complex [Mn(L 1 )2(NCS)2] (1) along with the atomic numbering scheme. The neutral monomeric complex consists of a central manganese atom surrounded by two L 1 ligands and two unidentate NCS− bonded through borderline N-atom to borderline Lewis acid Mn(II). The Mn atom is sitting at the center of inversion of a tetrahedron and one half of the molecule is symmetrical with the other half. Azoimidazoles act as both bidentate chelators, N(azo) and N(imidazole), as well as monodentate imidazole-N donor ligands. Here, each ligand is acting as a unidentate ligand. The metal center forms a stronger bond with thiocyanate-N (Mn1−N5 = 2.101) than with imidazole-N (Mn1−N1 = 2.228). The complexes are nonelectrolytes in nature. The NN bond length is 1.266(2), which is slightly greater than the free ligand (vide supra). The dihedral angle between the two least-squares planes is only 1.74°. Hence, complex formation forced the ligand to become more planar compared to the free ligand. Along the c axis the complex forms a flower mosaic structure (Figure b). The IR spectra of complex 1 exhibit a strong sharp stretch at 2090−2100 cm−1 along with a medium strong band at 770−775 cm−1 corresponding to νCN and νCS of a coordinated NCS group. Mn(II) does not form any bond with azo-N, which has little influence on the bond length and IR frequency of the -NN- group. The magnetic moment, μeff, is ∼5.2 BM at 300 K as expected for isolated S = 5/2 (d5) Mn(II) monomeric complexes.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of complex 2 contains a neutral monomeric [Cu(L 1 )2Cl2] molecule (Figure a). The copper center has a more nearly tetrahedral geometry. Cu−N bonds are much stronger than the Cu−Cl bonds. Both the chloride ion and the (imidazole)N−H of the complex form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds extending through the structure. The significant distortion toward the energetically unfavorable tetrahedral geometry observed in complex 2 appears to be a consequence of the bulkiness of the ligands and formation of very stable hydrogen bonding networks in the crystal. Along the a axis it forms a helical network (Figure b), with two chloride ions forming a square grid network along the b axis.

elements.content: The molecular structure of complex 3 is shown in Figure a. The structure shows a distorted tetrahedral structure with ZnN2Cl2 coordination. In the coordination zone two chloride groups and the two L 1 act as monodentate imidazole-N donor ligands. The distortion from a regular tetrahedral geometry is reflected from the metric parameters: Zn−N(imidazole) (Zn1−N1 = 2.0341(14) and Zn1−N5 = 2.0134(15) Å) is shorter than Zn−Cl (Zn1−Cl1 = 2.2403(6) and Zn1−Cl2 = 2.3436(6) Å). The NN distances are different for two bonded L 1 . The ligand with the smaller NN distance (N7−N8 = 1.248(2)) than free L 1 is more planar (the dihedral angle between the two least-squares planes is only 1.14°). On the other hand ligand units having a longer NN distance (N7−N8 = 1.261(2)) are less planar (the dihedral angle between the two least-squares planes is only 5.41°). Unlike complex 1, the tetrahedron is not a symmetric one. Here, both the chloride is directed in the opposite direction of the ligand. The imidazole unit is coordinated to the metal center from the opposite direction. Asymmetric unit contains one water of crystallization. Packing along the a axis shows the intermolecular hydrogen bonded network. One of the imidazole N−H forms an intermolecular hydrogen bond with the chloride ion and another one forms an intermolecular hydrogen bond with the water molecule. The water molecule forms a strong intermolecular hydrogen bond with chloride and imidazole N−H, which results in the formation of a hydrogen bonded chain along the b axis (Figure b).

elements.content: View of the molecular structure of complex 4 with an atom numbering scheme is shown in Figure a. The distorted RuN4Cl2 octahedron coordination is generated by the coordination of two chloride ions and two bidentate chelated L 1 . The Ru atom is sitting at the center of inversion of an octahedron and one half of the molecule is symmetrical with the other half, similar to complex 1. Both the chloride ions occupy the axial position. L 1 is acting as a bidentate ligand. Hence, the NN bond length is largely elongated (1.297(3)) compared to the free azo bond (vide supra). The increase in bond length is undoubtedly due to coordination of N(azo) to Ru because of dπ(Ru) → π*(azo) back-donation. The Ru−N(azo) bond is slightly shorter than Ru−N(imidazole), which is indicative of metal−ligand π-interaction that is localized in the M-azo fragment. In the solid-state each chloride ion forms strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds with neighboring (imidazole)N−H and results in the formation of a 2D hexagon layer along the a axis. In the solid-state it forms a flower mosaic architecture (Figure b) along the c axis.

elements.content: The molecular structure of the nonionic complex 5 is shown in Figure a. The Cd metal is surrounded by two unidentate L 1 and two chloride ion in a tetrahedral fashion. The metal ion is away from the center of inversion of the tetrahedron. Both the Cd−Cl bonds are largely elongated compared to the Cd−N bonds. Both the ligands are disposed in the opposite direction with respect to the Cd−N bond. Both the NN bonds are similar to that of free ligand as azo-N is not involved in bonding with the metal center. The asymmetric unit contains one water molecule. It forms stronger hydrogen bonds between (imidazole)N−H and the chloride ion. Chloride forms strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds with water and (imidazole)N−H. Overall intermolecular hydrogen bonding results in the formation of a 3D square grid network (Figure b), and it is an infinite chain of (CdL2Cl2H2O) n . In the solid-state water forms a linear wave along the a axis.

elements.content: Cadmium permits a wide variety of geometries and coordination numbers for its d10 configuration. We have tried to exploit its coordination behavior by changing the solvent of crystallization. When crystallization took place in the presence of dry ethanol we got mononuclear complex (6) without any water of crystallization in contrast to complex 5. This solvent-induced change in coordination behavior in the solid-state is attributed to factors such as crystal packing, hydrogen-bonding forces, relative Cd−Cl bond strength, and ease of formation of the cadmium chloride framework. Complex 6 crystallizes as infinite CdCl2 chains in which cadmium atoms are doubly bridged by pairs of chloride atoms; ligand completes the pseudo-octahedral coordination of the cadmium atoms (Figure a) and links the CdCl2 chains to form extended 3D layers. In both the complexes the Cd−N(imidazole) bond length is within the range of typical Cd−Naromatic bonding distances. The Cd−Cl bond lengths in both complexes are also within the range of typical values. In complex 6, one of the Cd−Cl bond lengths is relatively higher, whereas in complex 5 both are in the normal range. This increase in Cd−Cl bond length in 6 is because of the increased electron density at the cadmium with donation from the softer electron-rich azo-N. This has been suggested as the reason for similar systematic structural changes observed in a series of cadmium halide complexes with chelating nitrogen macrocyclic ligands. The CdCl2 chains propagate and stack along the a axis. In contrast to complex 5, in complex 6 the ligand is almost planar (⟨C1−N3−N4−C4 = 179.83°). In complex 5 both ortho and meta C−H groups form short contacts with the Cl atom while in 6 only one ortho C−H group forms C−H···Cl type interactions. We observe NN bond elongation (1.265(3) Å) compared to the free ligand, as azo-N participates in the coordination to the metal center. It forms a self-assembled ladder structure along the b axis (Figure b).

elements.content: Cadmium and mercury are chemically similar and we could predict structurally identical compounds of L 1 . However, when L 1 is treated with HgCl2 in the presence of NH4SCN it forms a complex of the structure of composition [L 1 ]2[Hg(SCN)4]. As shown in Figure a, the structure of compound 7 consists of a simple ionic salt of two mono cationic ligands L1 and tetrathiocyanatomercurate dianions. SCN− is an ambidentate ligand. It binds to soft/border line metal ions by the S-donor center that makes the metal ions softer than its precursor. The symbiosis is the leading force for the formation of central dianion without the coordination from the ligand. The tetrahedral coordination of Hg(II) of the anion is fulfilled by four monodentate SCN ligands. The sp2 N atom of the imidazole ring in L 1 is protonated. Each of the terminal N atoms of the SCN ligands forms strong hydrogen bonds with neighboring N−H of the L 1 . Tetrahedral anion takes a propeller shape and is surrounded by cationic L 1 . Planar monocationic L 1 stacks along the b axis forming a 2D sheet structure. Each of the 2D layers is interconnected by the central complex anion forming a 3D chain along the diagonal of the ac plane (Figure b). The molar conductance (ΛM) of complexes lies between 100 and 120 Ω1 cm2 mol− 1 suggesting a 1:1 type electrolytic nature of the compounds.

elements.content: L 1 shows a broad intraligand π−π* transition band centered around 361 nm, which depends on pH and metal ions. At acidic pH (∼2.0) L 1 shows a blue-shifted peak (355 nm), while in basic pH (∼10.0) it shows a red-shifted peak (390 nm) with a shoulder at 421 nm. Mn(II) complex shows two weak MLCT and d−d transitions at >400 nm along with a ligand transition at 357 nm. This supports the Td-Mn(II) coordination environment. Figure shows the absorption spectra of L 1 when titrated with Cu(II). Ligand absorption at 361 nm decreases with the simultaneous appearance of a peak at 422 nm with an isobestic point at 392 nm. Both Cd(II) and Zn(II) complexes show a red-shifted peak at 371 nm corresponds to the intraligand charge transfer transitions along with a shoulder at 424 nm which may be assigned to the d10(Zn/Cd) → π*(L 1 ) transition. The Zn(II) complex shows an extra peak at 304 nm. The Ru(II) complex exhibits a weaker broad metal to ligand charge transfer (MLCT) transition at 470 nm and intraligand π → π* transitions at 360 nm. The MLCT absorption band is assigned to dπ(Ru) → π*(L1 ) transition.

elements.content: Cyclic voltammetric (CV) studies were performed to investigate the extent of stabilization of the different oxidation states as well as the possible ligand oxidation. In addition, the CV results will also help in understanding the accessibility of the higher oxidation states and the effect of the ligand architecture on the redox potential. L 1 shows only one quasi-reversible (E pa = (−) 0.432 V, E pc = (−) 0.568 V, ΔE p = 136 mV and E 1/2 = (−) 0.50 V) redox response (Figure ). The redox behavior of the ligand is similar to the previously reported aryl azo imidazole systems. Mn-complex 1 shows a couple at >1.0 V versus SCE is referred to as the Mn(III)/Mn(II) redox process. The quasi-reversibility of the process is examined from the peak-to-peak separation, ΔE p > 100 mV. The one electron nature of the redox process has been compared with the current height data of the Ferrocene couple. Copper complex 2 shows the reversible CV response (ΔE p = 70 mv) corresponds to the Cu(II)/Cu(I) redox process. The nature of the voltammogram does not change with the scan rate. However, the ligand based peak remains almost similar to that of the free ligand in both complexes.

Electrochemical Studies

In addition, the CV results will also help in understanding the accessibility of the higher oxidation states and the effect of the ligand architecture on the redox potential. L  1  shows only one quasi-reversible (E pa = (-) 0.432 V, E pc = (-) 0.568 V, ΔE p = 136 mV and E 1/2 = (-) 0.50 V) redox response (Figure ). The redox behavior of the ligand is similar to the previously reported aryl azo imidazole systems. Mn-complex 1 shows a couple at >1.0 V versus SCE is referred to as the Mn(III)/Mn(II) redox process. The quasi-reversibility of the process is examined from the peak-to-peak separation, ΔE p > 100 mV. The one electron nature of the redox process has been compared with the current height data of the Ferrocene couple. Copper complex 2 shows the reversible CV response (ΔE p = 70 mv) corresponds to the Cu(II)/Cu(I) redox process. The nature of the voltammogram does not change with the scan rate. elements.content: Thermal characterizations of the products were accomplished by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The onset temperature of weight loss and decomposition temperature were 160 and 190 °C, respectively, for the free ligand L 1 . Metal-azo dyes were thermally more stable than that of the azo-dye. Both complexes 3 and 5 decomposed thermally in a number of steps. These complexes show successive thermal release of water of crystallization and the chloride followed by complete decomposition of the complex. The robustness of the solid-state framework is reflected in TGA. TGA of complex 3 in N2 atmosphere shows the release of one crystal water molecule (110−140 °C; Δm = 3.61% Calc.; 3.25% found) and two chloride ions (190−240 °C; Δm = 14.77% calc.; 15.23% found) (Figure ), which is in good agreement with the X-ray crystal structure. Complete decomposition is achieved at ∼310 °C. For complex 5, dehydration occurs at a slightly higher temperature range than that of 3 (130−160 °C; Δm = 3.29% calc.; 3.02% found), but the release of two chloride ion occurs at the same temperature range at 200−240 °C (Δm = 13.45% calc.; 13.16% found). Complete decomposition is achieved at ∼300 °C. However, complex 6 shows the release of four chloride ions in the broad temperature range of 200−250 °C (Δm = 39.94% calc.; 39.21% found) followed by complete decomposition at ∼330 °C. TGA curves of the complexes are sharp and show good thermal capability. These data show that the Zn and Cd complexes would possibly be able to fabricate a small and sharp recording mark edge. The higher the decomposition temperature of the complex, the smaller is the thermal interference. The sharper the decomposition curve, the higher is the sensitivity. On the basis of literature data, thermally stable compounds up to 250 °C are suitable for use as recording dyes, so according to the thermal stability of the azo-dye complexes we can conclude that these compounds are suitable for use as recording dyes.

elements.content: PXRD patterns also confirm the crystalline nature of the complexes. PXRD patterns of complex 3 show significant changes in the peak positions as well as intensities before and after water removal (Figure ). After heating the crystal of 3 at 150 °C for 3 h in a muffle furnace, PXRD data were recorded. Loss of overall crystallinity after water removal confirms that the stability of the solid-state framework due to formation of strong hydrogen-bonding interactions involving the crystal water molecule. A similar observation was made with complex 5.

elements.content: In conclusion, we achieved improved control of 3D solid-state structures by tuning the molecular level control in the coordination sphere. We have synthesized and characterized a series of seven metal complex of the 2-phenylazo imidazole ligand. The simultaneous presence of hydrogen bonding site and metal coordination site tune the coordination environment of metal complexes. We have shown here that a simple mixed donor ligand (L1 ) acts as an efficient building block for a 3D self-assembled structure in the solid-state. The crystals of the complexes also showed formation of multifaceted networks in the resulting complexes. Solvent-induced changes have been observed in the molecular level structure of complexes 5 and 6. Subtle changes in the coordination environment in complex 5 and 6 are responsible for the drastic differences in the resulting 3D structures in the solid-state, which is also reflected in their thermal behavior. Thermal studies show that most of the metal-azo dyes had good thermal stability up to 300 °C, which is an important criterion to be a recording material for DVD-R. We are currently extending this strategy to the other derived compounds of this ligand and their solid-state structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we achieved improved control of 3D solid-state structures by tuning the molecular level control in the coordination sphere. We have synthesized and characterized a series of seven metal complex of the 2-phenylazo imidazole ligand. The simultaneous presence of hydrogen bonding site and metal coordination site tune the coordination environment of metal complexes. We have shown here that a simple mixed donor ligand (L1 ) acts as an efficient building block for a 3D self-assembled structure in the solid-state. The crystals of the complexes also showed formation of multifaceted networks in the resulting complexes. Solvent-induced changes have been observed in the molecular level structure of complexes 5 and 6. Subtle changes in the coordination environment in complex 5 and 6 are responsible for the drastic differences in the resulting 3D structures in the solid-state, which is also reflected in their thermal behavior. Thermal studies show that most of the metal-azo dyes had good thermal stability up to 300 °C, which is an important criterion to be a recording material for DVD-R. We are currently extending this strategy to the other derived compounds of this ligand and their solid-state structures.

cln_elements.content:
2-(Phenylazo)imidazole ligand (L 1 ) was synthesized following the literature method.

General Synthesis of Metal Complexes

. L 1 (2 mmol) in MeOH (20 mL) was added dropwise to a stirred alcoholic solution (20 mL) of metal chloride salt (1 mmol) at RT. The mixture was stirred for another 1−3 h at RT. For complexes 1 and 7 excess NH4SCN was added to the mixture. The resulting solution was filtered and left undisturbed for crystallization. For the crystallization of complex 5 mixtures of water and ethanol were used.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

2-(Phenylazo)imidazole ligand (L  1 ) was synthesized following the literature method. 

General Synthesis of Metal Complexes

. L  1  (2 mmol) in MeOH (20 mL) was added dropwise to a stirred alcoholic solution (20 mL) of metal chloride salt (1 mmol) at RT. The mixture was stirred for another 1-3 h at RT. For complexes 1 and 7 excess NH4SCN was added to the mixture. The resulting solution was filtered and left undisturbed for crystallization. For the crystallization of complex 5 mixtures of water and ethanol were used.

cln_elements.content:
L 1 shows a broad intraligand π−π* transition band centered around 361 nm, which depends on pH and metal ions. At acidic pH (∼2.0) L 1 shows a blue-shifted peak (355 nm), while in basic pH (∼10.0) it shows a red-shifted peak (390 nm) with a shoulder at 421 nm. Mn(II) complex shows two weak MLCT and d−d transitions at >400 nm along with a ligand transition at 357 nm. This supports the Td-Mn(II) coordination environment. Figure shows the absorption spectra of L 1 when titrated with Cu(II). Ligand absorption at 361 nm decreases with the simultaneous appearance of a peak at 422 nm with an isobestic point at 392 nm. Both Cd(II) and Zn(II) complexes show a red-shifted peak at 371 nm corresponds to the intraligand charge transfer transitions along with a shoulder at 424 nm which may be assigned to the d10(Zn/Cd) → π*(L 1 ) transition. The Zn(II) complex shows an extra peak at 304 nm. The Ru(II) complex exhibits a weaker broad metal to ligand charge transfer (MLCT) transition at 470 nm and intraligand π → π* transitions at 360 nm. The MLCT absorption band is assigned to dπ(Ru) → π*(L1 ) transition.

Thermal and Powder XRD Analysis

Thermal characterizations of the products were accomplished by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The onset temperature of weight loss and decomposition temperature were 160 and 190 °C, respectively, for the free ligand L 1 . Metal-azo dyes were thermally more stable than that of the azo-dye. Both complexes 3 and 5 decomposed thermally in a number of steps. These complexes show successive thermal release of water of crystallization and the chloride followed by complete decomposition of the complex. The robustness of the solid-state framework is reflected in TGA. TGA of complex 3 in N2 atmosphere shows the release of one crystal water molecule (110−140 °C; Δm = 3.61% Calc.; 3.25% found) and two chloride ions (190−240 °C; Δm = 14.77% calc.; 15.23% found) (Figure ), which is in good agreement with the X-ray crystal structure. Complete decomposition is achieved at ∼310 °C. For complex 5, dehydration occurs at a slightly higher temperature range than that of 3 (130−160 °C; Δm = 3.29% calc.; 3.02% found), but the release of two chloride ion occurs at the same temperature range at 200−240 °C (Δm = 13.45% calc.; 13.16% found). Complete decomposition is achieved at ∼300 °C. However, complex 6 shows the release of four chloride ions in the broad temperature range of 200−250 °C (Δm = 39.94% calc.; 39.21% found) followed by complete decomposition at ∼330 °C. TGA curves of the complexes are sharp and show good thermal capability. These data show that the Zn and Cd complexes would possibly be able to fabricate a small and sharp recording mark edge. The higher the decomposition temperature of the complex, the smaller is the thermal interference. The sharper the decomposition curve, the higher is the sensitivity. On the basis of literature data, thermally stable compounds up to 250 °C are suitable for use as recording dyes, so according to the thermal stability of the azo-dye complexes we can conclude that these compounds are suitable for use as recording dyes.
